root.tree-val: North American Pidgins and Creoles: Ethnologue 2005
root.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)
root.pub-comments: This tree is an amalgamation of subtrees of the pidgin and creole trees provided in Ethnologue. It has been broken into regions for ease of searching.

child.tree-val: North American Pidgins and Creoles: Ethnologue 2005
child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)

child.tree-val: North American Pidgins and Creoles: Ethnologue 2005
child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)
child.alt-names: Patwa, Patois, Bongo Talk, Quashie Talk, Southwestern Caribbean Creole English
child.geography: Jamaicia, also spoken in Canada, Costa Rica, Dominican Republic, Panama, United Kingdom, USA.
child.pub-comments: The basilect (extreme varieties) and Standard English are inherently unintelligible to each other's speakers (Voegelin and Voegelin, LePage, Adler). It may be partly intelligible to speakers of Cameroon Pidgin and Krio of Sierra Leone, spoken by descendants of Jamaicans repatriated between 1787 and 1860. Inherently intelligible to speakers of creoles in Panama and Costa Rica. Reported to be very close to Belize Creole, close to Grenada, Saint Vincent, different from Tobago, very different from Guyana, Barbados, Leeward and Windward islands. Lexical similarity 25% with Guyanese, 13% with Belizean, 9% with Trinidadian, 8% with Barbadian, 5% with Nicaraguan.

child.tree-val: North American Pidgins and Creoles: Ethnologue 2005
child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)
child.geography: Costa Rica, east of San José, principally along the railroad between Siquirres and Limón, and south of Limón along the road.
child.pub-comments: Jamaican migrants settled in Limón about the middle of the 19th century, as they also did in Panama, so those varieties are close. Some say they do not understand Islander Creole English of San Andrés. Most speakers have limited comprehension of Standard English.

child.tree-val: North American Pidgins and Creoles: Ethnologue 2005
child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)
child.geography: Panama, Bocas del Toro, Colón, and Rio Abajo in Panama City.
child.pub-comments: Influences from both eastern and western Caribbean Creole English.

child.tree-val: North American Pidgins and Creoles: Ethnologue 2005
child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)
child.alt-names: Northern Central America Creole English, Kriol, Creola
child.pub-comments: Jamaican Creole is different in orthography and grammar.

child.tree-val: North American Pidgins and Creoles: Ethnologue 2005
child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)

child.tree-val: North American Pidgins and Creoles: Ethnologue 2005
child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)

child.tree-val: North American Pidgins and Creoles: Ethnologue 2005
child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)
child.geography: USA, coastal region from Jacksonville, North Carolina to Jacksonville, Florida, and especially on the Sea Islands off the Georgia coast. Small clusters in New York City and Detroit.
child.pub-comments: Barely understandable with Standard English. Intelligibility of other English-based creoles is undetermined. Very close to Bahamas Creole and Afro-Seminole. Lexical similarity 90% with Afro-Seminole. Linguistic influences from Fula, Mende, upper Guinea coast, Gambia River area (Hancock 1987).

child.tree-val: North American Pidgins and Creoles: Ethnologue 2005
child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)

child.tree-val: North American Pidgins and Creoles: Ethnologue 2005
child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)

child.tree-val: North American Pidgins and Creoles: Ethnologue 2005
child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)

child.tree-val: North American Pidgins and Creoles: Ethnologue 2005
child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)
child.geography: USA. Bracketville, Texas. Also spoken in Mexico.
child.pub-comments: Separated from coastal Sea Islands Creole between 1690 and 1760. Similar to Sea Islands Creole of USA and Bahamas Creole. Lexical similarity 90% with Sea Islands Creole. No speakers left in Oklahoma. Probably absorbed by Bahamian on Andros Island and by Spanish in Cuba.

child.tree-val: North American Pidgins and Creoles: Ethnologue 2005
child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)

child.tree-val: North American Pidgins and Creoles: Ethnologue 2005
child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)
child.geography: Mexico, Nacimiento de los Negros, Coahuila.

child.tree-val: North American Pidgins and Creoles: Ethnologue 2005
child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)

child.tree-val: North American Pidgins and Creoles: Ethnologue 2005
child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)
child.geography: Guyana, Georgetown, coast, and Rupununi River area. There may be some in French Guiana. Also spoken in Suriname, USA.
child.pub-comments: It may be intelligible with other English-based creoles of the Caribbean. Closest to creoles of Saint Vincent and Tobago. Rupununi may be a separate language. Speakers of Rupununi, Berbice Creole Dutch, and Skepi Creole Dutch claim they are not inherently intelligible with each other.

child.tree-val: North American Pidgins and Creoles: Ethnologue 2005
child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)

child.tree-val: North American Pidgins and Creoles: Ethnologue 2005
child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)

child.tree-val: North American Pidgins and Creoles: Ethnologue 2005
child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)

child.tree-val: North American Pidgins and Creoles: Ethnologue 2005
child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)

child.tree-val: North American Pidgins and Creoles: Ethnologue 2005
child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)
child.geography: USA, all the Hawaiian Islands, USA mainland (especially the west coast, Las Vegas, and Orlando).
child.pub-comments: The basilect (heavy creole) is barely intelligible with Standard English (H. McKaughan and M. Forman 1982). There is a continuum of speech from the distinct creole to Standard English of Hawaii.

child.tree-val: North American Pidgins and Creoles: Ethnologue 2005
child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)

child.tree-val: North American Pidgins and Creoles: Ethnologue 2005
child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)
child.alt-names: Kiryol, Portuguese Creole, Kriulo, Guinea-Bissau Creole
child.geography: Guinea-Bissau. Also Bijagos Islands. Also spoken in Gambia, Senegal, USA.
child.pub-comments: The Senegal dialect is different from Guinea-Bissau, with some Pidgin French vocabulary. Intelligible with Guinea-Bissau Creole.

child.tree-val: North American Pidgins and Creoles: Ethnologue 2005
child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)
child.geography: Cape Verde Islands, Sotavento dialect is on Santiago, Maio, Fogo, and Brava islands; Barlavento dialect is on Santo Antão, São Vicente, São Nicolau, Sal, and Boa Vista islands. Also spoken in France, Germany, Italy, Luxembourg, Netherlands, Portugal, Senegal, Spain, USA.

child.tree-val: North American Pidgins and Creoles: Ethnologue 2005
child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)

child.tree-val: North American Pidgins and Creoles: Ethnologue 2005
child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)
child.geography: USA, predominantly in St. Martin parish (St. Martinville, Breaux Bridge, Cecilia), New Roads and Edgard, Louisiana, parts of east Texas, small community in Sacramento, California.
child.pub-comments: Different from Standard French, the Cajun French also spoken in Louisiana, Haitian Creole French, and others of the Caribbean.

child.tree-val: North American Pidgins and Creoles: Ethnologue 2005
child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)

child.tree-val: North American Pidgins and Creoles: Ethnologue 2005
child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)
child.geography: Indonesia (Maluku), Central Maluku, Ambon, Haruku, Nusa Laut, Saparua Islands, along the coastal areas of Seram, and southern Maluku. Also spoken in Netherlands, USA.
child.pub-comments: Marginal intelligibility of Indonesian. Difficult intelligibility of Ternate Malay; speakers switch to Indonesian. Lexical similarity 81% with Standard Malay. Developed from Bazaar Malay and still reflects some archaic forms. Further diverged by adapting to the vernaculars of central Maluku. Considered to be a Malay-based creole by B. D. Grimes (1988, 1991) and J. Holm (1989:581–583).

child.tree-val: North American Pidgins and Creoles: Ethnologue 2005
child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)

child.tree-val: North American Pidgins and Creoles: Ethnologue 2005
child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)

child.tree-val: North American Pidgins and Creoles: Ethnologue 2005
child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)

child.tree-val: North American Pidgins and Creoles: Ethnologue 2005
child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)
child.geography: USA, formerly in the Middle Atlantic region.

child.tree-val: North American Pidgins and Creoles: Ethnologue 2005
child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)
child.geography: USA, formerly in the lower Mississippi River valley area, south central USA.
child.pub-comments: Muskogean-based pidgin, formerly used as lingua franca. Loanwords from Spanish, English, French, Creek, Alabama-Koasati, Choctaw, Chickasaw.

child.tree-val: North American Pidgins and Creoles: Ethnologue 2005
child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)
child.geography: Canada, British Columbia. Also spoken in USA. Formerly used along the Pacific coast from Oregon to Alaska, between Indian and White, and between speakers of different languages.
child.pub-comments: Consists mainly of words from Chinook, with a large admixture of words from Nootka, Canadian French, and English.

tree.description: North American Pidgins and Creoles: Ethnologue 2005
